questions.question: Which of the following words describes a property that is commonly used to classify solids?

answers.explanation: Most solids keep their shape because they are rigid.
Pourable describes liquids.
Gases, not solids, are easily compressed.
This is a property of liquids and gases.

questions.question: During the syringe investigation, which state of matter could be compressed the MOST?

answers.explanation: Gases have no fixed volume and can be compressed significantly.

questions.question: You sort a stop sign, a post-box and a tomato into one group. What common property best explains this grouping?

answers.explanation: Colour is the shared property for this grouping.

questions.question: In science, what two characteristics must something have to be classified as matter?

answers.content: It must have mass and volume (take up space).

questions.question: Explain in one sentence why liquids cannot be compressed easily.

answers.content: The particles in a liquid are already packed closely together, so pushing them closer is very difficult.

questions.question: The Ooho edible water orb is best described as:

answers.content: A liquid enclosed by a thin solid film
answers.explanation: The orb contains liquid water surrounded by a solid biodegradable membrane.

answers.content: A gas trapped in a solid

questions.question: When you press the plunger on a syringe filled only with air and then let go, the plunger ‘bounces’ back. What is the BEST explanation?

answers.content: Air turns into a liquid when compressed.
The compressed gas expands when the pressure is released, pushing the plunger back.
answers.explanation: Gases return to their original volume when pressure is removed.

answers.content: The syringe barrel is elastic and springs back.

questions.question: Draw one example of a solid, a liquid and a gas. Next to each drawing list ONE key property that justifies the classification.

answers.content: Teacher-scored drawing and property list (e.g., brick – rigid shape; water – flows and takes shape of container; steam – spreads to fill space).
answers.explanation: Responses will vary; award 1 mark per correct state with suitable property.

questions.question: Which property below is LEAST useful for deciding whether an object is a solid, liquid or gas?

answers.content: Whether it keeps a fixed shape

answers.explanation: Colour does not determine the state of matter.

questions.question: Name the fourth state of matter and give ONE natural place where it can be found.

answers.content: Plasma – found in stars (e.g., the Sun) / lightning / auroras.

questions.question: Which property of gases allows the smell of a cake baking in the kitchen to reach a bedroom at the other end of a house?

answers.explanation: Compression is about pressing gas into a smaller volume and is not related to odour movement.

answers.content: Gases flow from one place to another
answers.explanation: Because gases flow, the odour-carrying gas particles move through air currents from the kitchen to other rooms.
All matter has mass but this does not explain how smells travel.

answers.content: Gases take the shape of their container
answers.explanation: This property describes how gases fill a container, not how they move through open air.

questions.question: During Investigation 2 (Waterproof Paper) the tissue in the inverted cup remained dry when the cup was pushed straight down into the water. What does this observation show?

answers.explanation: Mass was not investigated in this activity.

answers.content: Air occupies space and prevents water from entering the cup
answers.explanation: The trapped air inside the cup takes up space, keeping water out so the tissue stays dry.
Paper normally absorbs water; the dry tissue was due to the trapped air, not water repulsion.
Air does dissolve slowly in water but it did not dissolve during the short investigation.

questions.question: When vinegar and baking soda reacted in Investigation 3 (Gas Bag), which gas inflated the bag?

answers.explanation: Oxygen is not produced in this reaction.
The acid–carbonate reaction releases carbon dioxide, which filled the bag.
Nitrogen is the main gas in air but was not created in the reaction.
Hydrogen is produced by some metal–acid reactions, not by vinegar and baking soda.

questions.question: List any THREE observable properties that can be used to identify a substance as a gas.

answers.content: Sample answer: (1) A gas takes the shape of its container and fills it; (2) A gas can be compressed; (3) A gas flows/moves from one place to another; (4) A gas has mass; (5) A gas has volume.
answers.explanation: Any three correct properties earn full marks. One mark for two correct properties, two marks for three.

questions.question: A scuba diver lifts two identical cylinders – one full of compressed air and one ‘empty’.  Which observation correctly explains why the full cylinder feels heavier?

answers.content: Metal of the full tank is thicker
answers.explanation: Both cylinders are made from the same material.

answers.content: Compressed air adds extra mass to the tank
answers.explanation: Air is matter with mass; more air particles are squeezed into the full tank, so its mass increases.

answers.content: Water has leaked into the full tank
answers.explanation: Scuba cylinders are filled only with air, not water.

answers.content: The empty tank has a vacuum that pushes up
answers.explanation: The ‘empty’ tank still contains air at normal pressure, not a vacuum.

questions.question: Explain briefly why a helium-filled weather balloon rises in Earth’s atmosphere.

answers.content: Helium is less dense (lighter per volume) than the surrounding air, so the balloon experiences an upward buoyant force and rises.
answers.explanation: Density difference between the helium inside and the air outside creates buoyancy.

questions.question: Which statement best defines the term viscosity?

answers.content: A measure of how easily a liquid flows.
answers.explanation: Viscosity is the resistance of a liquid to flow; high viscosity = flows slowly, low viscosity = flows quickly.

answers.content: A measure of how quickly a solid melts.
The temperature at which a liquid boils.
The amount of space a gas occupies.

questions.question: Which of the following household liquids would you expect to have the HIGHEST viscosity at room temperature?

answers.explanation: Honey flows much more slowly than water or oil, indicating a higher viscosity.

questions.question: In the ‘Runny Honey’ race-track experiment, name the ONE variable you deliberately changed to make it a fair test.

answers.content: The type of liquid (or "kind of liquid")
answers.explanation: Only the liquid was changed; all other factors such as volume, distance and angle were kept constant.

questions.question: List TWO variables that had to be kept the same (controlled) in the viscosity experiment.

answers.content: Any two of: volume of liquid used, length of the track/distance travelled, surface material of the track (same tray/tile), angle/height the track is tilted, starting line position, room temperature.
answers.explanation: Keeping these factors constant ensures that only the type of liquid affects the time taken to reach the finish line.

questions.question: According to the rules of a fair test, how many independent variables should be changed at one time?

answers.explanation: Changing only one variable allows you to link any differences in the results to that single variable.

questions.question: Explain why the newly released ‘squeezy’ Vegemite must have a LOWER viscosity than regular jar Vegemite.

answers.content: Because the product must flow easily through the nozzle when squeezed; this requires it to be thinner (lower viscosity) than the thicker paste found in jars.

questions.question: When you measure the time it takes a liquid to travel from the start line to the finish line, what property are you really measuring?

answers.explanation: A longer time indicates a higher viscosity (slower flow).

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram of your viscosity ‘race-track’ set-up showing the start line, finish line, angle of tilt and the three liquids being tested.
When matter is heated it usually …

answers.explanation: Heat gives particles more energy so they move apart and occupy more space.

questions.question: In the ‘Amazing Self-Inflating Balloon’ demonstration, which state of matter inside the bottle was mainly responsible for inflating the balloon?

answers.explanation: The air (gas) inside the bottle expanded when heated, pushing into the balloon.

questions.question: Why does water ‘break the rules’ compared with most other substances when it freezes in the bottle?

answers.content: It contracts on freezing, pulling the bottle walls inward.
It expands on freezing, increasing its volume and bursting the bottle.
answers.explanation: Ice has an open crystal structure that occupies more space than liquid water.

answers.content: It turns directly into gas leaving a vacuum.
Nothing unusual happens; the bottle is just weak.

questions.question: Give a one-sentence definition of thermal shock.

answers.content: Thermal shock is the cracking or breaking of a material caused by a very rapid change in temperature that creates uneven expansion or contraction.

questions.question: The liquid inside a traditional glass thermometer rises mainly because …

answers.content: the liquid expands as it warms
answers.explanation: Increased temperature gives the liquid particles more energy, so they move apart and take up more space along the narrow bore.

questions.question: Explain why bridges include expansion joints.

answers.content: Expansion joints allow the concrete or metal parts of a bridge to expand on hot days and contract on cold days without buckling or cracking, protecting the bridge’s structural integrity.

questions.question: Running the metal lid of a glass jar under hot water helps open it because …

answers.content: the metal expands more than the glass, loosening the seal
answers.explanation: Metals generally expand more quickly than glass with heat, so the lid’s diameter increases slightly and releases its grip.

answers.content: the contents of the jar evaporate
air pressure inside the jar increases dramatically

questions.question: Draw two simple particle diagrams: one showing a sample of gas at a low temperature and one at a higher temperature. Use arrows or spacing to indicate the change in particle movement and spacing.

answers.content: Full marks: Both diagrams show the same number of particles; high-temperature diagram has particles spaced further apart and/or with larger motion arrows; low-temperature diagram has particles closer with shorter arrows. Partial marks: Shows only one correct feature or omits equal particle number.
